questions.text: A 9-month-old child was admitted to ICU with a history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media by Staphylococcus aureus. Blood test shows decreased serum IgA, IgG, IgM, IgE, and plasma B cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bruton syndrome

Explanation

The decreased serum IgA, IgG, IgM, IgE, plasma B cells and the recurrent infections suggest the diagnosis of Bruton syndrome which is an X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

Brutons’s Disease:

  • Also Known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) caused by mutations in the BTK (Bruton’s tyrosine kinase) gene present on the q22 long arm of the X chromosome.
  • Defective B-cell maturation leads to an absence of mature B cells and very low levels of all immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM).
  • Clinical features: Presents after 6-9 months of age. Recurrent bacterial infections (eg- encapsulated bacteria like Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus influenzae) starting around 6 months of age including otitis media, pneumonia, and sinusitis, Neutropenia and enterovirus infections.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Absence of B cells (CD19+ cells) in peripheral blood and
    • Markedly low immunoglobulin levels
    • No germinal centres in lymph nodes

Ataxia-Telangiectasia (Option A) is characterized by cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias, and immunodeficiency. The immunodeficiency is variable with low immunoglobulins and T cells. There is common IgA deficiency (selective absence of IgA in 50-80 %); impaired T- and B-cell responses; and small, disorganized thymus.

Chronic granulomatous disease (Option B) is due to the reduced activity of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase, leading to impaired generation of superoxide radicals. It presents with persistent smouldering pneumonia, prominent lymphadenitis, multiple liver abscesses, osteomyelitis of small bones of hands and feet, recurrent, life-threatening infections usually by catalase-positive bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia) and fungi (e.g., Aspergillus)

DiGeorge syndrome (Option D) is caused by microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2 and presents with cardiac anomalies, abnormal facies, thymic hypoplasia/ aplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemic tetany.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, and erythematous desquamation of the skin. A 2D echocardiogram shows coronary aneurysms. What is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IVIG

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation—fever, conjunctival congestion, strawberry tongue, and erythematous desquamation—along with coronary aneurysms on echocardiography, is highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome). The first-line treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) combined with aspirin, aimed at reducing inflammation and preventing coronary artery complications.

Kawasaki Disease (KD)

 

Etiology and Pathophysiology
  • Higher incidence in children of Asian descent.
  • Vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries, especially coronary arteries.

Pathology

Acute Phase (Days 1-10):

  • Neutrophilic inflammation of blood vessels.
  • Infiltration of inflammatory cells, vessel wall swelling and damage.

 

Subacute Phase (Weeks 2-4): Risk of fusiform aneurysm formation as inflammation subsides.

 

Convalescent Phase (Weeks >4 weeks): Resolution of inflammation; potential scarring and thickening of arterial walls leading to stenosis.

Clinical Features

 
  • Fever: For at least 5 days.
  • Extremities: Swelling, redness, peeling skin around nails, fingers, and toes.
  • Mucocutaneous: Bilateral conjunctivitis, red and cracked lips, "strawberry tongue," and pharyngeal congestion.
  • Polymorphous Rash: Various forms (macular, papular, target-like lesions).
  • Cervical Lymphadenopathy: Unilateral, painful swelling of neck lymph nodes.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

 

Fever lasting at least 5 days.

 

At least 4 of the following:

 

5-“CREAM” features

 

  • C - Conjunctivitis, B/L non-purulent
  • R - Rash involving trunk
  • E- Erythema & Edema of palms & soles along with desquamation
  • A - Adenopathy (usually unilateral, cervical)
  • M- Mucositis (Strawberry Tongue)

 

Laboratory Findings:

  • Elevated CRP and ESR.
  • Elevated WBC count.
  • Echocardiography coronary artery aneurysms.

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction.
  • Coronary Artery Aneurysms.
  • Coronary Artery Stenosis:

Differential Diagnosis

Bacterial Infections (e.g., Scarlet Fever, Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome): Fever, rash, mucosal involvement with additional features like sore throat or blistering.

Treatment
  • Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): Reduces inflammation and lowers risk of aneurysms.
  • Aspirin: High doses initially to reduce inflammation and fever; then low-dose regimen for anti-platelet effects.

 

IVIG-Resistant KD:

  • Second dose of IVIG, corticosteroids, or other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., infliximab, cyclosporine).

 

Aspirin (Option A): Important in treatment but is not the first-line therapy alone. It complements IVIG to control inflammation and reduce thrombotic risks.

Clopidogrel (Option C): Antiplatelet agent used for specific coronary conditions but not a primary treatment for Kawasaki disease.

LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin) (Option D): Used in cases with significant thrombotic complications but not first-line therapy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool. Lab investigations revealed normal platelet count and urine analysis shows haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

  • The clinical scenario of purpura in legs and buttocks, arthritic pain, abdominal pain and normal platelet level are characteristic of Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP).

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)

 

 

Aetiology
  • The exact cause is unknown.
  • Immune-mediated vasculitis, often following an upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition, with HLA-B34 and DRB1, was observed in some cases.
  • Most common in Males.

 

 

Pathology and Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation of small blood vessels affecting skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys.
  • Triggered by immune system response to infections.
  • Leakage of fluid and blood cells into tissues.
  • Immune complex deposition, particularly IgA, in affected vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Palpable Purpura: Raised, purplish-red rash, mainly on lower limbs and buttocks.
  • Joint Involvement: Joint swelling, commonly in knees and ankles.
  • Abdominal Pain: Often severe, may include vomiting, diarrhoea, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception
  • Renal Involvement: Less common, presents as Chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

  • Palpable purpura plus at least one of:
    • Diffuse abdominal pain
    • Arthritis or arthralgia
    • Biopsy-proven IgA deposition
    • Renal involvement (hematuria &/ proteinuria)


Laboratory involvement:

  • Elevated ESR or CRP indicates inflammation.
  • Platelet Counts are normal.

Complications
  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic Renal Failure due to Long-term kidney damage, in severe cases.
  • Neurological Complications: Rare; may include seizures, headaches, or peripheral neuropathy.

Treatment
  • Mild Cases: Rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
  • Moderate to Severe Cases: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation.
  • Severe or Resistant Cases: Additional immunosuppressive medications may be required.

Prognosis
  • Full recovery in most cases.
  • Variable based on renal involvement.


Malar rash is virtually pathognomonic in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option A). It involves the cheek, bridge of the nose, and lower eyelids but characteristically spares the nasolabial folds.

In Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) (Option C), children present with a sudden appearance of bruises and mucosal bleeding like epistaxis, oral oozing and prolonged bleeds with superficial trauma. The platelet levels are low in this condition unlike the given scenario.

Polyarteritis arteritis nodosa (Option D) rare in childhood, is characterised by the presence of either a biopsy showing small and mid-size artery necrotising vasculitis or angiographic abnormalities.

questions.text: A child was brought to OPD with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. Whereas laboratory tests revealed normal platelet counts. What will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Henoch-Schonlein purpura

  • The clinical scenario of palpable blanching purpura, arthritic pain, abdominal pain with normal platelet count is characteristic of Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP).

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)

Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects small blood vessels, commonly seen in children. The characteristic clinical features include palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and renal involvement. Hematuria and proteinuria are common findings in urine examination due to kidney involvement. The symptoms may be preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection

Etiology
  • Most common in males.
  • Exact cause unknown.
  • Immune-mediated vasculitis, often following an upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition, with HLA-B34 and DRB1 observed in some cases.

Pathology and Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation of small vessels affecting skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys.
  • Triggered by immune system response to infections.
  • Leakage of fluid and blood cells into tissues.
  • Immune complex deposition, particularly IgA, in affected vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Palpable Purpura: Raised, purplish-red rash, mainly on legs and buttocks
  • Joint Involvement: Joint swelling, commonly in knees and ankles.
  • Abdominal Pain: Often include vomiting, diarrhea, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception.
  • Renal Involvement: Less common, presents as Chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

Palpable purpura plus at least one of the following:

  • Diffuse abdominal pain
  • Arthritis or arthralgia
  • Biopsy-proven IgA deposition
  • Renal involvement

Laboratory involvement:

  • Elevated ESR or CRP indicating inflammation.
  • Platelet Counts are normal.

Complications
  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic renal failure due to long term kidney damage, in severe cases.
  • Neurological complications: Rare; may include seizures, headaches, or peripheral neuropathy.

Treatment
  • Mild Cases: Rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
  • Moderate to Severe Cases: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation.
  • Severe or Resistant Cases: Additional immunosuppressive medications may be required.

While Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (Option A) can present with purpura and thrombocytopenia, it does not typically involve joint pain, abdominal pain or renal manifestations such as hematuria and proteinuria.

Dengue (Option B) is a viral infection that can cause fever, rash, joint pain and thrombocytopenia .

Churg Strauss syndrome (Option C) also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is a rare systemic vasculitis that primarily affects medium and small blood vessels. It is characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a child who has abdominal pain, haematuria, and palpable purpura over the leg, as depicted in the image, with IgA deposition observed on biopsy of the skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct option: Option B. HSP

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a condition associated with inflammation of blood vessels.
  • The causes of HSP are unknown.
  • HSP affects the small blood vessels of the body leading to rash, which is also known as purpura.
  • Following are the symptoms of HSP
  • a skin rash, which appears like small bruises or small reddish-purple spots – it is usually seen on the legs and around the elbows and buttocks.
  • Swelling of the feet and hands, and sometimes swelling of the scrotum in males.
  • Pain in the joints, mostly of knees and ankles, stomachache, blood in the faeces or urine.

Incorrect options:

Option A: IgA nephropathy is present with hematuria 1 to 3 days after the onset of upper respiratory tract infection. IgA nephropathy is also known as Berger disease.

Option C: RPGN is a Rapid loss of Renal function following GN presents with Oliguria/Anuria, Raised renal function test, and Bleeding manifestations.

Option D: PSGN, i.e., post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, occurs 1 to 2 weeks after the onset of upper respiratory tract infection, and it is also associated with haematuria.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 9-year-old boy with knee joint swelling, non-blanching rashes (as shown in the picture), haematuria +++ and proteinuria + on urine examination, and normal platelet levels?
questions.solution:
Correct option is B

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a type of vasculitis that primarily affects small blood vessels. It is most commonly seen in children. HSP is characterized by inflammation and damage to blood vessels, which can lead to a variety of symptoms. The key features in this case that point towards HSP are:
  1. Swelling of knee joints:
  2. Non-blanching rashes (purpura)
  3. Haematuria +++ and proteinuria
  4. Normal platelet levels

Incorrect Option 

Options A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is an autoimmune disease that can also affect multiple organs, including joints, skin, and kidneys. However, in this case, the presence of non-blanching rashes (purpura) and normal platelet levels is more suggestive of HSP rather than SLE.

Options C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP is a condition characterized by low platelet levels and abnormal bleeding. The presence of normal platelet levels in this case makes ITP an unlikely diagnosis.

Options D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is a systemic vasculitis that affects medium and small arteries. It typically presents with symptoms such as fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and muscle/joint pain. The combination of non-blanching rashes (purpura) and kidney involvement is not typical of PAN.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent infections and failure to thrive. Laboratory investigations reveal a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Adenosine deaminase (ADA) is essential for purine metabolism.
    ADA deficiency → accumulation of deoxyadenosine → toxic to lymphocytes. This causes severe deficiency of both T cells and B cells, leading to SCID.

Clinical presentation:

  • Presents in infancy: recurrent bacterial, viral, fungal, and opportunistic infections.
  • Failure to thrive is common due to chronic infections and malnutrition.

Management:

  • Lymphopenia, low/absent immunoglobulins, absent thymic shadow on chest X-ray.
  • Treatment: hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; enzyme replacement therapy is also available.

Hypogammaglobulinemia (Option B): Only B-cell defect; ADA deficiency affects both B and T cells.

DiGeorge Syndrome (Option C): Caused by 22q11.2 deletion → thymic aplasia; not related to ADA metabolism.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (Option D): X-linked defect in WAS gene → eczema, thrombocytopenia, immunodeficiency; not due to purine metabolism defect.

 

Disease

Defect

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)

Most commonly IL-2 receptor γ-chain (X-linked) or adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome

WAS protein defect (X-linked) — cytoskeletal reorganization in lymphocytes impaired

Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia

Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) defect (X-linked) — B-cell maturation failure

Hyper-IgM syndrome

CD40 ligand (CD40L) defect on T-cells (X-linked) — class switching defect

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD)

NADPH oxidase defect — absent respiratory burst in neutrophils

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 1

CD18 integrin subunit defect — defective leukocyte migration/chemotaxis

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

LYST (lysosomal trafficking regulator) defect — microtubule dysfunction in phagosome–lysosome fusion

DiGeorge syndrome

22q11 deletion — failure of 3rd/4th pharyngeal pouch development → absent thymus & parathyroids

Ataxia–telangiectasia

ATM gene defect — impaired DNA double-strand break repair

Complement (C1 esterase) inhibitor deficiency

C1 esterase inhibitor defect — hereditary angioedema
